title: Syntax error when using multiple `cfg` attributes

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-parser
labels.description: Area: The parsing of Rust source code to an AST.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

labels.name: D-terse
labels.description: A diagnostic that doesn't give enough information about the problem at hand

body:
I encountered a weird behavior when using `cfg(test)` and `cfg(not(test))`.

I tried this code:

```rust
fn does_not_work() -> usize {
    #[cfg(not(test))]
    0

    #[cfg(test)]
    1
}
```

Results in:

```bash
   Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error: expected one of `.`, `;`, `?`, `}`, or an operator, found `#`
 --> src/lib.rs:6:5
  |
4 |     0
  |      - expected one of `.`, `;`, `?`, `}`, or an operator
5 | 
6 |     #[cfg(test)]
  |     ^ unexpected token

error: aborting due to previous error

error: could not compile `playground`.

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

**Workaround**

```rust
fn does_work() -> usize {
    #[cfg(not(test))]
    return 0; // `return` including a semicolon

    #[cfg(test)]
    1
}
```

### Meta

Rust stable version 1.47.0

Playground: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=f7f7eb30327396c209b0f358b1a3072b
